    • Field Detail

      • LOCAL_DATE

        public static final org.nustaq.serialization.FSTBasicObjectSerializer LOCAL_DATE
        FST serializer for LocalDate.

        I have found that FST, when using a custom serializer, doesn't write/read all possible short values consistently. If we write a short like so: 

           out.writeShort(myShort);
        ..and read like so: 
           in.readShort();
        Then for some short values, what is read will be different from what was written, causing ChronicleMapRealBenchmark using SerializationFramework.FST_CUSTOM to fail (if assertions are enabled) and only if the benchmark that use SerializationFramework.FST_VANILLA executed first. This implies that FST has undesirable side-effects somewhere.

        writeShort() actually accept an int which could be the first sign something is fucked up? But even if we replace the write method to this: 

           out.getCodec().writeFShort(myShort);
        ..the problem still doesn't go away. And yes, I've tried many flavors of night hacks.

        So this implementation currently write/read 2 bytes instead of a short. But, according to my testing, this doesn't affect the byte size of the serialized container. I have not yet investigated how our hack affect the time cost, but I suspect there is no significant impact.

      • BIG_DECIMAL

        public static final org.nustaq.serialization.FSTBasicObjectSerializer BIG_DECIMAL
